trans-unit.source: Call an API app from an authenticated client
trans-unit.target: Call an API app from an authenticated client

trans-unit.source: Learn how to call an Azure API app from a web app client that is authenticated by Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to call an Azure API app from a web app client that is authenticated by Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Call an Azure API app from a web app client authenticated by Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Call an Azure API app from a web app client authenticated by Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to call an API app that is protected by Azure Active Directory (AAD) from a web app that is also protected by AAD.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to call an API app that is protected by Azure Active Directory (AAD) from a web app that is also protected by AAD.

trans-unit.source: When you finish the tutorial, you'll have a web app and an API app running in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: When you finish the tutorial, you'll have a web app and an API app running in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: The web app will display data that it gets by calling the API app, as shown in the following screen shot.
trans-unit.target: The web app will display data that it gets by calling the API app, as shown in the following screen shot.

trans-unit.source: You'll learn how to pass on AAD credentials from the web app to the API app so that the user is not prompted again by the API app to log in.
trans-unit.target: You'll learn how to pass on AAD credentials from the web app to the API app so that the user is not prompted again by the API app to log in.

trans-unit.source: You'll perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: You'll perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Create an API app and configure it to use AAD authentication.
trans-unit.target: Create an API app and configure it to use AAD authentication.

trans-unit.source: Create a web app and configure it to use AAD authentication.
trans-unit.target: Create a web app and configure it to use AAD authentication.

trans-unit.source: Add code to the web app to call the protected API app.
trans-unit.target: Add code to the web app to call the protected API app.

trans-unit.source: Deploy both the web app and the API app to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Deploy both the web app and the API app to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Test to verify that the web app can call the API app.
trans-unit.target: Test to verify that the web app can call the API app.

trans-unit.source: Client flow authentication
trans-unit.target: Client flow authentication

trans-unit.source: The code that you add to the web app will implement a process called <link><linkText>client flow</linkText><title></title></link> authentication.
trans-unit.target: The code that you add to the web app will implement a process called <link><linkText>client flow</linkText><title></title></link> authentication.

trans-unit.source: The following diagram illustrates the process for getting the AAD access token and exchanging it for an API app (Zumo) token.
trans-unit.target: The following diagram illustrates the process for getting the AAD access token and exchanging it for an API app (Zumo) token.

trans-unit.source: If you're not familiar with the role of the API app gateway in authentication for API apps, see <link><linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you're not familiar with the role of the API app gateway in authentication for API apps, see <link><linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Before starting this tutorial, make sure that you have <link><linkText>Visual Studio 2015</linkText><title></title></link> and the <link><linkText>Azure SDK for .NET</linkText><title></title></link> installed.
trans-unit.target: Before starting this tutorial, make sure that you have <link><linkText>Visual Studio 2015</linkText><title></title></link> and the <link><linkText>Azure SDK for .NET</linkText><title></title></link> installed.

trans-unit.source: The same instructions will also work for Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: The same instructions will also work for Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial assumes that you know how to work with web projects in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial assumes that you know how to work with web projects in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Create and secure an API app using AAD
trans-unit.target: Create and secure an API app using AAD

trans-unit.source: Create or download an API app project.
trans-unit.target: Create or download an API app project.

trans-unit.source: To create a project, follow the directions in <link><linkText>Create an API app</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To create a project, follow the directions in <link><linkText>Create an API app</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To download a project, get it from the <link><linkText>ContactsList GitHub repository</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To download a project, get it from the <link><linkText>ContactsList GitHub repository</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You now have a Web API project that returns contact data.
trans-unit.target: You now have a Web API project that returns contact data.

trans-unit.source: Deploy the API app project to a new API app in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Deploy the API app project to a new API app in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Follow the directions in <link><linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Follow the directions in <link><linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure preview portal], the API Definition blade for the API app now shows the Get and Post methods of the Web API project that you deployed.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure preview portal], the API Definition blade for the API app now shows the Get and Post methods of the Web API project that you deployed.

trans-unit.source: Secure the API app by using Azure Active Directory (AAD) as the identity provider.
trans-unit.target: Secure the API app by using Azure Active Directory (AAD) as the identity provider.

trans-unit.source: Follow the directions for AAD in <link><linkText>Protect an API app</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Follow the directions for AAD in <link><linkText>Protect an API app</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You don't need to do the Use Postman to send a Post request section of the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You don't need to do the Use Postman to send a Post request section of the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: When you're done, the API app's Azure Active Directory blade in the [Azure preview portal] has the AAD application's client ID and your AAD tenant.
trans-unit.target: When you're done, the API app's Azure Active Directory blade in the [Azure preview portal] has the AAD application's client ID and your AAD tenant.

trans-unit.source: And the AAD application's Configure tab in the [Azure portal] has the API app's App ID URL and Reply URL.
trans-unit.target: And the AAD application's Configure tab in the [Azure portal] has the API app's App ID URL and Reply URL.

trans-unit.source: Create and secure a web app using AAD
trans-unit.target: Create and secure a web app using AAD

trans-unit.source: In this section you download and configure a web project that is set up for AAD authentication.
trans-unit.target: In this section you download and configure a web project that is set up for AAD authentication.

trans-unit.source: The project has an About page that shows claims information for the logged-on user.
trans-unit.target: The project has an About page that shows claims information for the logged-on user.

trans-unit.source: You'll modify this page later by adding a section for displaying contact information retrieved from the API app.
trans-unit.target: You'll modify this page later by adding a section for displaying contact information retrieved from the API app.

trans-unit.source: Download the web project from the <link><linkText>WebApp-GroupClaims-DotNet repository</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Download the web project from the <link><linkText>WebApp-GroupClaims-DotNet repository</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions for How to run the sample in the Readme file, with the following exceptions:
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions for How to run the sample in the Readme file, with the following exceptions:

trans-unit.source: You can use Visual Studio 2015 although the Readme file says to use Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: You can use Visual Studio 2015 although the Readme file says to use Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: Use the AAD application you already created instead of creating a new one.
trans-unit.target: Use the AAD application you already created instead of creating a new one.

trans-unit.source: Keep the same App ID URI that you already have for the AAD application.
trans-unit.target: Keep the same App ID URI that you already have for the AAD application.

trans-unit.source: (Don't change it to the format specified in the Readme file.)
trans-unit.target: (Don't change it to the format specified in the Readme file.)

trans-unit.source: You're keeping the same App ID URI that you created for the API app so that you can use the same AAD access token for both the web app and the API app.
trans-unit.target: You're keeping the same App ID URI that you created for the API app so that you can use the same AAD access token for both the web app and the API app.

trans-unit.source: If you changed the App ID URI to the format prescribed by the readme, that would work for access to the web app but not for the API app.
trans-unit.target: If you changed the App ID URI to the format prescribed by the readme, that would work for access to the web app but not for the API app.

trans-unit.source: You wouldn't be able to pass the AAD token to the API app gateway to get a Zumo token because the gateway expects a token for an App ID URI composed of the gateway URL plus "/login/aad".
trans-unit.target: You wouldn't be able to pass the AAD token to the API app gateway to get a Zumo token because the gateway expects a token for an App ID URI composed of the gateway URL plus "/login/aad".

trans-unit.source: Add generated client code for the API app
trans-unit.target: Add generated client code for the API app

trans-unit.source: In this section you add automatically generated code for a typed interface for calling the API app.
trans-unit.target: In this section you add automatically generated code for a typed interface for calling the API app.

trans-unit.source: In Visual studio Solution Explorer, right-click the WebApp-GroupClaims-DotNet project, and then click Add > Azure API App Client.
trans-unit.target: In Visual studio Solution Explorer, right-click the WebApp-GroupClaims-DotNet project, and then click Add > Azure API App Client.

trans-unit.source: In the Add Microsoft Azure API App Client dialog box, select the API app that you secured with AAD.
trans-unit.target: In the Add Microsoft Azure API App Client dialog box, select the API app that you secured with AAD.

trans-unit.source: Once code generation is complete, you see a new folder in Solution Explorer, with the name of the API app.
trans-unit.target: Once code generation is complete, you see a new folder in Solution Explorer, with the name of the API app.

trans-unit.source: This folder contains the code that implements the client classes and data models.
trans-unit.target: This folder contains the code that implements the client classes and data models.

trans-unit.source: Fix ambiguous references caused by the generated code in ContactsList/ContactsExtensions.cs: change the two instances of Task.Factory.StartNew to System.Threading.Tasks.Task.Factory.StartNew.
trans-unit.target: Fix ambiguous references caused by the generated code in ContactsList/ContactsExtensions.cs: change the two instances of Task.Factory.StartNew to System.Threading.Tasks.Task.Factory.StartNew.

trans-unit.source: Add code to exchange the AAD token for a Zumo token
trans-unit.target: Add code to exchange the AAD token for a Zumo token

trans-unit.source: In HomeController.cs, add using statements for the App Service SDK and JSON serializer.
trans-unit.target: In HomeController.cs, add using statements for the App Service SDK and JSON serializer.

trans-unit.source: Add constants for the gateway URL and the App ID URI of the AAD application.
trans-unit.target: Add constants for the gateway URL and the App ID URI of the AAD application.

trans-unit.source: Make sure the gateway URL is https, not http.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the gateway URL is https, not http.

trans-unit.source: Add a method that gets a client object for calling the API app.
trans-unit.target: Add a method that gets a client object for calling the API app.

trans-unit.source: In this code ConfigHelper.Authority resolves to "https://login.microsoftonline.com/{your tenant}", for example: "https://login.microsoftonline.com/contoso.onmicrosoft.com".
trans-unit.target: In this code ConfigHelper.Authority resolves to "https://login.microsoftonline.com/{your tenant}", for example: "https://login.microsoftonline.com/contoso.onmicrosoft.com".

trans-unit.source: Add code immediately before the return View() statement at the end of the About method to call the API app.
trans-unit.target: Add code immediately before the return View() statement at the end of the About method to call the API app.

trans-unit.source: (In the following step you'll add code to the About view to display the returned data.)
trans-unit.target: (In the following step you'll add code to the About view to display the returned data.)

trans-unit.source: In Views/Home/About.cshtml, add code immediately after the h2 heading to display the contact information.
trans-unit.target: In Views/Home/About.cshtml, add code immediately after the h2 heading to display the contact information.

trans-unit.source: In the application Web.config file, add the following binding redirect after the opening tag.
trans-unit.target: In the application Web.config file, add the following binding redirect after the opening tag.

trans-unit.source: Without this binding redirect, the app will fail because the App Service SDK includes a dependency on System.Net.Http.Primitives version 1.5.0.0 but the version used by the project is 4.2.28.0.
trans-unit.target: Without this binding redirect, the app will fail because the App Service SDK includes a dependency on System.Net.Http.Primitives version 1.5.0.0 but the version used by the project is 4.2.28.0.

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions in Deploy this sample to Azure in the Readme file.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions in Deploy this sample to Azure in the Readme file.

trans-unit.source: Run the app.
trans-unit.target: Run the app.

trans-unit.source: Click Sign in, and then enter the credentials of a user in the AAD domain you're using for this application.
trans-unit.target: Click Sign in, and then enter the credentials of a user in the AAD domain you're using for this application.

trans-unit.source: Click About.
trans-unit.target: Click About.

trans-unit.source: The code you added to the About controller and view runs and shows that you successully authenticated to the API app and called its Get method.
trans-unit.target: The code you added to the About controller and view runs and shows that you successully authenticated to the API app and called its Get method.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting

trans-unit.source: HTTP 400 errors
trans-unit.target: HTTP 400 errors

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the gateway url is https, not http.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the gateway url is https, not http.

trans-unit.source: When copied directly out of the Azure preview portal, it may specify http.
trans-unit.target: When copied directly out of the Azure preview portal, it may specify http.

trans-unit.source: SQL Server errors
trans-unit.target: SQL Server errors

trans-unit.source: The application requires access to a SQL Server database identified by the GroupClaimContext connection string.
trans-unit.target: The application requires access to a SQL Server database identified by the GroupClaimContext connection string.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the connection string in the deployed site points to a SQL Database instance.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the connection string in the deployed site points to a SQL Database instance.

trans-unit.source: You can put the correct connection string in the deployed Web.config or in the Azure runtime configuration settings.
trans-unit.target: You can put the correct connection string in the deployed Web.config or in the Azure runtime configuration settings.

trans-unit.source: Acknowledgments
trans-unit.target: Acknowledgments

trans-unit.source: Thanks to Govind S. Yadav (<link><linkText>@govindsyadav</linkText><title></title></link> for help developing this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Thanks to Govind S. Yadav (<link><linkText>@govindsyadav</linkText><title></title></link> for help developing this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: You've seen how to do client flow authentication for App Service API apps.
trans-unit.target: You've seen how to do client flow authentication for App Service API apps.

trans-unit.source: For information about other ways to handle authentication in API apps, see <link><linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about other ways to handle authentication in API apps, see <link><linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title></link>.
